article.title: Initial Demonstration Of 9-MHz Framing Camera Rates On The FAST Drive Laser Pulse Trains

multiple_choice_question.text: What information is shown in Figure 3 regarding the drive laser green component?
choices: Time evolution of the laser pulse train at 3 MHz.
Focus mode image with horizontal and vertical projections, and Gaussian fitting results.
Demonstration of the tracking of beam size and position of consecutive green micropulses.
Vertical slow sweep image of 20 micropulses with 10-Âµs sweep range.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 depict in the context of the experiment?
choices: Spatial distribution of the green laser component after passing through the streak camera.
Focus mode image of the streak camera, limited by the entrance slits.
A series of micropulses with a slow vertical sweep, illustrating the ability to track bunch-by-bunch centroid motion.
The experimental setup for the framing mode camera, including the slow vertical sweep and horizontal deflection units.

multiple_choice_question.text: What adjustment was made to the experimental setup in Figure 5 compared to Figure 4?
choices: The laser repetition rate was increased to 9 MHz.
The number of micropulses displayed was reduced to achieve better temporal resolution.
The vertical sweep range was expanded to capture a larger portion of the pulse train.
The horizontal deflection was turned off to focus on the vertical profile of the micropulses.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of using OTR in Figure 7 compared to previous figures?
choices: It allows for the measurement of the laser pulse duration with higher accuracy.
It demonstrates the ability to apply the framing mode technique to individual electron beam micropulses.
It eliminates the need for the green laser component, simplifying the experimental setup.
It provides information about the spatial distribution of the electron beam in both transverse planes.
